snippet: Two different epidemics have prompted eerily similar reactions from health officials and the public, raising crucial questions about why the world remains persistently unprepared to react to the emergence of viral threats.
abstract: Dr Lawrence K Altman The Doctor's World column observes Ebola epidemic and HIV epidemic of early 1980s have prompted eerily similar reactions from health officials and public, raising crucial questions about why the world remains persistently unprepared to react to the sudden emergence of viral threats.
lead_paragraph: Two different epidemics have prompted eerily similar reactions from health officials and the public, raising crucial questions about why the world remains persistently unprepared to react to the emergence of viral threats.

headline.seo: Like AIDS Before It, Ebola Isn’t Explained Clearly by Officials
